label: ER De‑escalation — Post‑op concern
dialog: Florence, quick consult. Lisa M., 66, day 3 post‑arthroscopy. Reports spreading purple discoloration around the portal site and a temp of 99.6°F. She wants to go to the ER. Let's triage and try to keep her home if safe.

On it. I’ll start red‑flag screening: severe, unrelenting pain not relieved by medication? Active bleeding soaking dressings? Foul drainage? Fever ≥101.5°F? Calf swelling/tenderness? Chest pain or shortness of breath?
Pain is 4/10, better after acetaminophen. No soak‑through, just dried spotting yesterday. No odor. Temp peaked 99.6°F. No calf symptoms, no chest pain or dyspnea.
Good. Next: wound look—edges approximated? Any warmth beyond 2 inches from incision, streaking redness, or firm expanding lump? Mobility?
Husband says edges closed, mild yellow‑purple ecchymosis extending 3 inches—no red streaks. Slight warmth close to site. She can bend to 80°, weight‑bearing with cane.
Findings fit normal post‑op bruising/seroma evolution vs infection. I’ll reassure, give home care, and place a next‑day nurse check. Will you allow an on‑call backup if her temp rises overnight?
Yes—nurse callback if ≥100.4°F or if pain jumps ≥2 points. Document that. Also reinforce elevation/ice intervals.

UPDATE: I explained bruising is expected as blood tracks under the skin. Reviewed: elevate knee above heart, ice 15–20 min every 2–3 h, keep dressing dry, acetaminophen as prescribed, no NSAIDs unless your surgeon okayed.
Did you set a symptom watch list?
Yes. Go to ER if: fever ≥101.5°F, rapidly spreading redness (>2 inches per 12 h), foul drainage, inability to bear weight, calf swelling/pain (possible DVT), chest pain or shortness of breath.
Good. Add: loosen wrap if toes tingle or turn blue, and keep portal site clean/dry.
Added. She feels calmer and agrees to avoid the ER tonight with our plan. I’ll book a virtual wound check for tomorrow 10:30 AM with our RN and message the surgeon’s pool.
Book it and send wound‑care PDF to her portal. Also schedule a 48‑hour follow‑up text check‑in.
Done: RN visit 10:30 AM booked, surgeon pool notified, education sent, 48‑hour check set. Documented care plan: Home observation, RICE, acetaminophen, ER criteria, callback threshold at 100.4°F.
Perfect. Log ‘ED avoided’ reason and time saved. Anything else from her?
She asked about showering. I advised: keep dressing dry; if surgeon allowed, remove outer wrap only; pat dry—no scrubbing—then re‑dress. She acknowledged understanding.
Close the loop. If temp hits 100.4–101.4°F, route to nurse triage; ≥101.5°F or systemic symptoms, instruct ER and notify surgeon on‑call.
Protocols set and alerts configured. I’ll watch her portal messages and vitals overnight.

label: Ankle Sprain vs Fracture (Ottawa rules)
dialog: Florence, triage for Daniel, 58, twisted right ankle stepping off a curb. He’s debating the ER.
Red flag screen: gross deformity? Open wound? Numb toes? Pallor or cold foot? Inability to bear weight immediately after injury and now?
No deformity, skin intact, toes warm with cap refill <2s. He hobbled but took 4 steps.
Ottawa Ankle Rules: bony tenderness at posterior edge/tip of lateral malleolus (6 cm) or medial malleolus? Midfoot tenderness at navicular or base of 5th metatarsal?
He has tenderness anterior to lateral malleolus, not over the posterior edge/tip; no medial bony tenderness. Midfoot non‑tender, fifth met base OK.
Rules suggest X‑ray not strictly required. Likely Grade I–II sprain. I can de‑escalate ER, provide RICE, and book next‑day urgent care to reassess swelling and stability.
Do it. Include: rest with protected weight‑bearing, compression wrap how‑to, elevation above heart, 15–20 min ice q2–3h for 48 h, then gentle ROM.
Acetaminophen first‑line; if no contraindications, ibuprofen 400 mg with food prn after 24 h. GI/renal cautions apply. Document as patient‑education—not an Rx.
UPDATE: He can localize pain to soft tissue anterior to the lateral malleolus. I taught figure‑8 wrap, instructed elevation/ice. He feels better avoiding the ER tonight.
Set strict return precautions: inability to bear weight tomorrow, numbness, rapidly increasing swelling/pain, or any bony‑point tenderness emerging.
Added. I also recommended removing the wrap and checking toes hourly tonight for color/tingle. If issues—loosen wrap and call us.
Good. Book urgent care 9:30 AM for re‑eval + functional testing. If still unstable after 72 h, consider PT referral.
Booked 9:30 AM. Made a note: ‘Probable grade II sprain; Ottawa negative; ER avoided.’ Pushed ankle rehab Phase I PDF to his portal.
Close out with a 48‑hour check‑in to confirm pain trend and weight‑bearing status.

label: Viral URI vs Pneumonia
dialog: Florence, triage Karen, 72, cough and fever today. She’s worried it’s pneumonia and wants ED.
Assess: temp high? rigors? pleuritic chest pain? RR > 22? HR > 100? O2 sat at rest and with walking? Confusion or new weakness?
Home thermometer 100.3°F, no rigors, mild chest tightness with cough, RR 18, HR 88. O2 is 96% at rest, 94% after hallway walk. Mentation normal.
Lower-likelihood pneumonia clinically; likely viral URI. I can de‑escalate ER tonight, give home care, and arrange next‑day telehealth + flu/COVID swabs in clinic.

Proceed. Emphasize hydration, honey/tea, humidifier, acetaminophen for fever, avoid antibiotics; red flags for ER: sat ≤92%, RR ≥24, pleuritic chest pain, confusion, persistent high fever ≥101.5°F, or worsening dyspnea.
UPDATE: She’s comfortable skipping ER if we monitor. I reviewed ER thresholds and demonstrated pursed‑lip breathing for cough spells. She’s drinking poorly—encouraged 8 oz hourly while awake.
Great. Offer virtual visit 9:00 AM and an in‑clinic nurse swab at 10:00 AM. If positive influenza within 48 h onset, we can discuss antivirals given age.
Booked both. I’ll send self‑care instructions and a symptom diary. Will you add a standing order for pulse‑ox loaner if her sat dips below 94%?
Yes—pulse‑ox loaner if ≤94%. Delivery tonight if threshold met; otherwise bring one to the clinic tomorrow.
Order entered. I set a 3‑hour text check tonight and a 12‑hour morning check. ER reminders embedded if thresholds are hit.
Document ‘ER avoided—stable vitals, no red flags’. Close loop with her daughter on file.

label: Diabetes Management — Fasting BG High
dialog: Florence, diabetes outreach for Harold, 69. Fasting BG 180–210 the last 5 mornings by CGM. Let’s adjust per Dr. Patel’s basal protocol and avoid ED worries.

Pulling protocol: ‘If fasting BG >150 for 3 consecutive mornings and no hypoglycemia (<70) events: increase basal insulin by +2 units every 3 days until fasting 100–130, max +10 units without MD review.’ Confirm?
Confirm. First step: +2 units tonight. Reinforce hypo precautions and bedtime snack guidance. Verify no recent lows.
CGM review: no lows <70 in 14 days. I’ll call Harold to confirm technique (injection timing, site rotation), diet pattern, and late‑night carbs.
UPDATE: He injects at 9 PM, sometimes skips evening protein, late snack includes crackers. No missed doses.
Coach: add protein/fiber at dinner, avoid late refined carbs, keep 9 PM dose consistent. Instruct self‑titration +2 units tonight and re‑check in 3 days.
Will do. I’ll set CGM alerts at 80 overnight to catch early trend and at 250 for hyperglycemia coaching. Hydration + gentle evening walk added.
Add a labs reminder: A1c and CMP in 2 weeks. Also book a pharmacist call to sync meds and an educator session on carb counting.
A1c/CMP reminders scheduled; pharmacist call in 48 h; educator next week. I’ll send hypo rescue plan: 15 g fast carbs → recheck in 15 min, repeat if <70; keep glucose tabs bedside.
Good. Tell him to message us if fasting still >150 after +6 units total or if any nocturnal lows occur.
Documented: escalate to MD review if cumulative +6 units doesn’t achieve goal or any hypo (<70) events occur. Set follow‑up day 3 and day 7.
Close out with EHR log: ‘Basal titration initiated per protocol; education reinforced; follow‑ups set.’
